page.title: 12POPULATION:DRAYTON BASSETT
page.content: In 1086 the village was a small farming community with 9 villeins, 3 bordars and 2 mills recorded in Domesday. By the 1801 census the population was still small (395), increasing to 508 in 1851. The numbers declined in the next decade to 441, further declining to the lowest recorded figure of 365 in 1921. This fits into a general trend of rural depopulation in the 19th century, with increased mechanisation of farming, and in this case, the decline of the Peel family fortunes with consequent cut backs on the estate. The population trend has been moving upwards since 1945 with the building of new housing estates (council and private) for Birmingham commuters. The population now stands at 711 (1982) and will increase in the future with more private housing planned in the village.
